pullRequest.body:
This continues a series of PRs on L-series.

Here we add `ArithmeticFunction.LSeriesHasSum` (in `NumberTheory.LSeries.Basic`) and `ArithmeticFunction.abscissaOfAbsConv` (in a new file `NumberTheory.LSeries.Convergence`), together with some results about these notions.

See [here](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/L-series/near/422275501) on Zulip.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

nodes.body: :v: MichaelStollBayreuth can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8065669558/job/22031966733)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8065669558/job/22031965969)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8065669558/job/22031966483)
Looks good to me!
Looks good to me!

**[imports]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ```
Maybe this lemma and the next might be better formulated as an "IsBigO" statement?
I'll think about that.

To be precise I meant that the hypothesis `h` could become `f =O[atTop] fun n => n ^ x`, which is almost definitionally equal to what you wrote but has a richer API attached to it I'm not suggesting any change to the conclusion of the lemma.

I have now added a "isBigO" version of `LSeriesSummable_of_le_const_mul_rpow`, which did require some additional work to deal with the fact that O() means that the bound holds eventually and not a priori everywhere, and then used that to provide "isBigO" versions of these two lemmas (in addition, as the other versions might still be useful).

I think this probably belongs elsewhere. There is a similar lemma (with `im` rather than `re`) inlined in `differentiableAt_jacobiTheta` (with a slightly different proof). It might be desirable to unify these somewhere, and treat left / right / upper / lower halfplanes together.

I don't think it makes much sense to "unify" them in the sense that one has one statement covering all of them. But it certainly makes sense to have four such lemmas together in a suitable place. What would be a reasonable file for them to live in?
Yes, that's what I meant (four separate lemmas in the same file). I don't have a view on which file this should be, but probably the `#find_home` routine will.

`#find_home(!)` does not produce anything useful. I think it is best to add a new file `Mathlib.Analysis.Complex.Halfplane` (which imports `Mathlib.Analysis.Complex.Basic` and `Mathlib.Topology.Instances.EReal`) for these four lemmas.
(I do not actually use the fact that a right half-plane is open in this PR, but it will come in handy in later contributions.)
Do we really need this file? It seems very specific and I don't see where it is used.

See the comments above.
I will need the right half-plane version eventually in a follow-up PR. If it helps, I can defer adding the material until it is actually needed.

Sorry, I didn't see the comment. Yes, let's defer those, you can even open a separate PR with only those results, this one is probably a little specialized to number theorist.

bors d+

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(NumberTheory/LSeries/*): add material on convergence
